case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Baldeo Prasad

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 271 of 1956 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 271 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated August 2, 1955 of Nagpur High Court in Misc. Petition No. 249 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 2, 1955, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Petition No. 249 of 1955. Adhikari,

facts.text: Certificate issued by Nagpur High Court under Article 132 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal with a certificate issued by the Nagpur High Court under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution raises a question about the validity

facts.text: State of Madhya Pradesh passed order on June 16, 1955 under section 4-A against respondent Baldeo Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: of the Central Provinces and Berar Goondas Act X of 1946 as amended by Madhya Pradesh Act XLIX of 1950. It appears that against the respondent Baldeo Prasad the State of Madhya Pradesh, appellant 1, passed an order on June 16, 1955, under s. 4-A of the Act.

facts.text: District Magistrate, Chhindwara passed order dated June 22, 1955 communicating the externment order to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently the District Magistrate, Chhindwara, appellant 2, passed another order dated June 22, 1955, companymunicating to the respondent the first externment order passed against him. The respondent then fileda writ petition

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition No. 249 of 1955 in High Court under Article 226 challenging validity of orders and Act.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then fileda writ petition in the High Court  No. 249 of 1955  under Art. 226 challenging the validity of the said orders, inter alia, on the ground that the Act under which the said orders were passed was itself ultra vires.

facts.text: Appellants disputed respondent's contention about vires of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants disputed the respondents companytention about the vires of the Act. The High Court, however, has upheld the respondents plea and has held that ss. 4 and 4-A of the Act are invalid,

facts.text: High Court held sections 4 and 4-A invalid, and whole Act invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, has upheld the respondents plea and has held that ss. 4 and 4-A of the Act are invalid, and since the two sections companytain the main operative provisions of the Act, according to the High Court, the whole Act became invalid.

facts.text: Central Provinces and Berar Goondas Act X of 1946 passed in 1946, came into force September 7, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed in 1946 and came into force on September 7, 1946. It was subsequently amended and the amended Act came into force on November 24, 1950.

facts.text: Act amended by Madhya Pradesh Act XLIX of 1950, came into force November 24, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It was subsequently amended and the amended Act came into force on November 24, 1950. As the preamble shows the Act was passed because it was thought expedient to provide for the companytrol of goondas

facts.text: State Government issued proclamation under Section 3 on August 10, 1954 specifying Police Stations Parasia, Jamai and Chhindwara Town as proclaimed area.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant 1 issued a proclamation under S. 3 on August 10, 1954, specifying the limits of Police Stations Parasia and Jamai and Chhindwara Town as proclaimed area. This proclamation was renewed in November, 1954 and February, 1955.

facts.text: Proclamation renewed in November 1954 and February 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This proclamation was renewed in November, 1954 and February, 1955. Thereafter on May 9, 1955, appellant 1 issued afresh proclamation specifying the whole of the Chhindwara District as the proclaimed area.

facts.text: Fresh proclamation issued May 9, 1955 specifying whole Chhindwara District as proclaimed area till August 8, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on May 9, 1955, appellant 1 issued afresh proclamation specifying the whole of the Chhindwara District as the proclaimed area. This proclamation was to remain in force till August 8, 1955.

facts.text: District Magistrate received reports from District Superintendent of Police against respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Whilst the second proclamation was in force the second appellant received reports from the District Superintendent of Police, Chhindwara, against the respondent, and he ordered the issue of a numberice to him

facts.text: Notice issued to respondent to show cause why action under s.4, to appear April 29, 1955; respondent served but did not appear.

anchor.surface_text: to show cause why action should number be taken against him under s. 4 this numberice required the respondent to appear before the second appellant on April 29, 1955. The respondent, though served, did number appear before the second appellant.

facts.text: District Magistrate sent report to State on April 30, 1955 with draft order for approval under proviso to s.4(1).

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the second appellant sent a report to appellant 1 on April 30, 1955, and submitted the case against him with a draft order for the approval of the said appellant under the first pro- viso to s. 4 1 .

facts.text: Fresh notice under s.4 issued to respondent on May 24, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime the third numberification was issued by appellant 1. The second appellant then issued a fresh numberice against the respondent under s. 4 on May 24, 1955.

facts.text: Respondent appeared on May 30, 1955, filed written statement on June 4, 1955; hearing fixed June 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appeared in person on May 30, 1955, and was given time to file his written statement which he did on June 4, 1955. The case was then fixed for hearing on June 22, 1955.

facts.text: State Government passed order on June 16, 1955 directing respondent not to remain in Chhindwara District until August 8, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile the State Government passed an order on June 16, 1955, directing that the respondent shall, except in so far as he may be permitted by the second appellant from time to time, number remain in any place in Chhindwara District.

facts.text: On June 22, 1955, District Magistrate communicated the order to respondent and directed him to leave district before 10 a.m. on June 23, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On June 22, 1955, the second appellant companymunicated the said order to the respondent and directed him to leave the District before 10 a. m. on June 23, 1955. The respondent appealed to appellant 1 to cancel the order passed against him.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to State Government; treated as representation under s.6, rejected on July 9, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellant treated the appeal as a representation made by the respondent under s. 6 and rejected it on July 9, 1955. A day before this order was passed the respondent filed his writ petition

facts.text: Writ petition filed a day before July 9, 1955 order.

anchor.surface_text: A day before this order was passed the respondent filed his writ petition in the High Court from which the present appeal, arises.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 3, 1960 by Gajendragadkar J.

anchor.surface_text: Adhikari, Advocate-General for the State of Madhya Pradesh, B. K. B. Naidu and I. N. Shroff, for the appellants. Patnaik, for the respondent. 1960. October 3.

facts.text: Respondent challenged Act as invading fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(d) and (e), invalid under Art.13.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the validity of the Act on the ground that it invades his fundamental rights under Art. 19 1  d  and  e  and as such it becomes invalid having regard to the provisions of Art. 13 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It has been urged before us that such an obligation is implicit in ss. 4 and 4-A.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed out s. 4-A suffers from the same infirmities as s. 4. Having regard to the two infirmities in ss. 4, 4-A respectively we do number think it would b

arguments.court_reasoning: Not impressed; statute must expressly impose duty for conditions precedent

arguments.claim: Purpose of Act to protect public order and safeguard citizens attracts protection of Art.19(5) prima facie

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, broadly stated the purpose of the Act is to safeguard individual rights and protect innocent and peaceful citizens against the prejudicial activities of goondas, and in that sense the Act may prima facie claim the benefit of Art. 19 5 .

arguments.claim: ss.4 and 4-A invalid due to infirmity: no requirement for District Magistrate to decide person is goonda before action

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that s. 4 contemplates preventive action... the primary condition precedent... is that the person... is a goonda and it is precisely in regard to this condition that the section suffers from a serious infirmity.

arguments.claim: Definition of 'goonda' in s.2 vague and provides no guidance/assistance for classification

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally it would also be relevant to point out that the definition of the word goonda affords no assistance in deciding which citizen can be put under that category. It is an inclusive definition...

arguments.claim: Infirmities lead to unfettered discretion, making restrictions unreasonable under Art.19(5)

anchor.surface_text: The result of this infirmity is that it has left to the unguided and unfettered discretion of the authority concerned to treat any citizen as a goonda. In other words, the restrictions... must... be held to be unreasonable.

arguments.claim: Provisions like ss.56,57 Bombay Police Act 1951 upheld as they include safeguards

anchor.surface_text: In this connection we may refer to the corresponding Bombay statute... s. 56 and s. 57... have been confirmed respectively in Bhagubhai... and Hari Khemu...

arguments.court_reasoning: Contrast with Goondas Act lacking safeguards

arguments.claim: If operative sections (ss.4,4-A) invalid, whole Act must fall

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that if the operative sections are invalid the whole Act must fall.

holdings.text: The legislative competence of the State Legislature to pass the Act cannot be disputed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Act relates to public order, within state list under 1935 Act; competence conceded.

holdings.text: Broadly stated the purpose of the Act is to safeguard individual rights and protect innocent and peaceful citizens against the prejudicial activities of goondas, and in that sense the Act may prima facie claim the benefit of Art. 19(5).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, broadly stated the purpose of the Act is to safeguard individual rights and protect innocent and peaceful citizens against the prejudicial activities of goondas, and in that sense the Act may prima facie claim the benefit of Art. 19 5 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preamble and scheme show control of goondas to protect public peace; falls under reasonable restrictions for public order.

holdings.text: The primary condition precedent for taking action under s. 4 is that the person against whom action is proposed to be taken is a goonda and it is precisely in regard to this condition that the section suffers from a serious infirmity.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.4 requires person to be goonda for action; no mechanism to determine status.

holdings.text: The section does not provide that the District Magistrate must first come to a decision that the person against whom he proposes to take action is a goonda, and gives him no guidance or assistance in the said matter.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of express duty on DM to classify person as goonda before preventive action; hearing limited to grounds, not status.

holdings.text: The definition of the word goonda affords no assistance in deciding which citizen can be put under that category. It is an inclusive definition and it does not indicate which tests have to be applied.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Inclusive definition lacks precision for classification, exacerbating infirmity.

holdings.text: We are, however, not impressed by this argument [that obligation is implicit in ss. 4 and 4-A].
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute must expressly impose duty for conditions precedent; silence is infirmity.

holdings.text: The restrictions which it allows to be imposed on the exercise of the fundamental right of a citizen guaranteed by Art. 19(1)(d) and (e) must in the circumstances be held to be unreasonable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Infirmities lead to arbitrary/unfettered power; violates reasonableness under Art.19(5); not saved.

holdings.text: That is the view taken by the High Court and we see no reason to differ from it.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses High Court's invalidity finding on ss.4,4-A.

holdings.text: There is no doubt that if the operative sections are invalid the whole Act must fall.
holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.4,4-A are main operative provisions; invalidity severs not possible.

holdings.text: Sections 27, 56 and 57 of Bombay Police Acts upheld as they provide safeguards.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Recalls prior Supreme Court precedents; illustrates valid alternatives with safeguards.
